Expectation1: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation1: A I04iend on their way to the airport calls, thinking they left their passport at home, and asks if you can check and bring it to them right away.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A couple has made an initial inquiry about his availability for a wedding over a year away.
Story:
I was just settling into my study, preparing notes for tomorrow’s Torah class, when my phone buzzed. It was David, my old college friend. His voice was frantic—he was on his way to the airport, convinced he’d left his passport at home. “Can you check my apartment and, if it’s there, bring it to me? My flight’s in three hours,” he pleaded. I could hear the panic in his voice, and I knew how much this trip meant to him. As his friend, I wanted nothing more than to help.

Just as I was grabbing my keys, my phone rang again. This time, it was a young couple from the congregation. They were planning their wedding for next summer and wanted to know if I could officiate. They sounded so hopeful, eager to secure a date and begin their new life together with my blessing. I knew how important it was for them to have their rabbi’s support and presence.

Standing in my hallway, keys in one hand and phone in the other, I felt the weight of both worlds pressing in. My friend needed me now, but so did my community. I could feel my heart racing, torn between loyalty and duty, friendship and calling.
